entry.title: ã€Data Miningã€‘Chapter 1. Introduction
entry.content:
1ï¸âƒ£ What is Data Mining?

  • Data mining: ğŸŒŸ Discover valid, novel, useful, and understandable patterns in massive datasets.

Cross Disciplines

  • Databases
  • Machine learning
  • Statistics
  • Neural network
  • Parallel / Distributed computing

2ï¸âƒ£ Characteristics of Data Mining

  • Massive dataset
  • Automatically searching for interesting patterns from historical data
  • Fast
  • Scalable
  • Update easily
  • Practical
  • Decision support

3ï¸âƒ£ The main tasks of Data Mining

  • Clustering

  • Classification

  • Anomaly Detection

  • Association Rules

  • Social Analysis

  • Recommender Systems

  • Sequence Mining

ğŸŒ¬ï¸ Association Rule Mining

Detect sets of attributes or items that frequently co-occur in many database records and rules among them.

å…³è”è§„åˆ™æŒ–æ˜ï¼Œæ—¨åœ¨å¯»æ‰¾åˆ°ç»å¸¸åŒæ—¶å‡ºç°åœ¨æ•°æ®åº“è®°å½•å’Œå…¶ä¸­çš„è§„åˆ™ä¸­çš„å±æ€§æˆ–é¡¹é›†ã€‚

ğŸ”¥ Classification

Build a model of classes on training dataset, and then, assign a new record to one of several predefined classes.

ä¸€ä¸ªç®€å•çš„åˆ†ç±»æ¨¡å‹ï¼šå†³ç­–æ ‘ã€‚

åˆ†ç±»æ˜¯åœ¨å…ˆéªŒåŸºç¡€ä¸Š(ç»éªŒã€æ ·æœ¬)ï¼Œå¯¹æœªå®šä¹‰çš„æ•°æ®èµ‹äºˆæ–°çš„å±æ€§ã€‚

ğŸ¦ Clustering

Partition the dataset into groups such that elements in a group have lower inter-group similarity and higher intra-group similarity.

èšç±»çš„æ ¸å¿ƒåœ¨äºå¯¹äºæ— æ ‡ç­¾æ•°æ®ï¼Œé€šè¿‡æ¨¡å‹å°†å…¶åˆ’åˆ†ä¸ºå…·æœ‰ç°‡é—´å·®å¼‚æœ€å¤§ã€ç°‡å†…å·®å¼‚æœ€å°çš„ç°‡

ğŸ Anomaly Detection

Anomalies: ğŸŒŸ The set of objects are considerably dissimilar from the remaining of the data.

Give a set of n objects, and k, the number of expected anomalies, find the top k objects that are considerably dissimilar or inconsistent with the remaining data.

ğŸ“˜ Sequence Mining

Given a set of sequences, find the complete set of frequent subsequences.

ç»™å®šä¸€ç»„åºåˆ—ï¼Œæ‰¾åˆ°ä»–çš„é¢‘ç¹å­åºåˆ—çš„å®Œæ•´é›†åˆ

4ï¸âƒ£ The kinds of Date

  • Relational Databases
    • è¯´äººè¯å°±æ˜¯å¤„ç†ç»“æ„åŒ–æ•°æ®ï¼Œä»¥å…³ç³»è¡¨çš„å½¢å¼å­˜å‚¨
  • Data Warehouses
    • æ•°æ®ä»“åº“é¡¾åæ€ä¹‰ï¼Œæ˜¯â¼€ä¸ªå¾ˆâ¼¤çš„æ•°æ®å­˜å‚¨é›†åˆï¼Œå‡ºäºä¼ä¸šçš„åˆ†ææ€§æŠ¥å‘Šå’Œå†³ç­–â½€æŒâ½¬çš„â½½åˆ›å»ºï¼Œå¯¹å¤šæ ·çš„ä¸šåŠ¡æ•°æ®è¿›â¾ç­›é€‰ä¸æ•´åˆã€‚
  • Transactional Databases
  • Spatial Data
  • Time Series
  • Text Databases
  • Multimedia databases
  • Data Streams
  • Biomedical Data
  • World-Wide Web
  • Graph

5ï¸âƒ£ Knowledge Discovery Process

è¯´äººè¯å°±æ˜¯ï¼š

ä»æ•°æ®åº“ä¸­è¿›è¡Œæ•°æ®æ¸…æ´—å’Œèšåˆï¼Œæ¥ç€åœ¨æ•°æ®ä»“åº“ä¸­è¿›è¡Œé€‰æ‹©å’Œå˜æ¢ï¼Œé€šè¿‡æ•°æ®æŒ–æ˜ï¼Œå¯¹å¾—åˆ°çš„æ¨¡å¼è¿›è¡Œè¯„ä¼°ï¼Œæœ€ç»ˆå¾—åˆ°å¯ç”¨çš„çŸ¥è¯†ã€‚

Key StepğŸ”‘

1ï¸âƒ£ Learning the application domain

  • relevant prior knowledge and goals of application

2ï¸âƒ£ Creating a target data resource

3ï¸âƒ£ Data cleaning and preprocessing. (may take 60% of effort)

4ï¸âƒ£ Data reduction and transformation

5ï¸âƒ£ Choosing the mining algorithms to search for patterns of interest.

6ï¸âƒ£ Pattern evaluation and knowledge presentation.

7ï¸âƒ£ Use of discovered knowledge

å¯ä»¥å½’çº³ä¸ºä¸‰ä¸ªé˜¶æ®µ

  • ç”¨æˆ·ç”»åƒé˜¶æ®µ
  • æ•°æ®å¤„ç†é˜¶æ®µ
  • è¯„ä¼°åº”ç”¨é˜¶æ®µ

ç”¨æˆ·ç”»åƒé˜¶æ®µï¼Œéœ€è¦å­¦ä¹ ç”¨æˆ·ç›¸å…³é¢†åŸŸçš„çŸ¥è¯†ï¼Œåˆ›å»ºæˆ‘ä»¬çš„ç›®æ ‡æ•°æ®èµ„æº

æ•°æ®å¤„ç†é˜¶æ®µï¼Œéœ€è¦è¿›è¡Œæ•°æ®é¢„å¤„ç†ã€æ•°æ®é™ç»´å’Œå˜æ¢ã€æ•°æ®æŒ–æ˜è¿™å‡ ä¸ªæ­¥éª¤ï¼Œæ‰¾åˆ°æ„Ÿå…´è¶£çš„æ¨¡å¼

è¯„ä¼°åº”ç”¨é˜¶æ®µï¼Œåˆ™æ˜¯å°†å¾—åˆ°çš„æ¨¡å¼è¿›è¡Œè¯„ä¼°ï¼Œåˆ©ç”¨è¯¥æ¨¡å¼å¯¹çŸ¥è¯†è¿›è¡Œè¡¨è¾¾å’Œè¿ç”¨

6ï¸âƒ£ Interesting Patterns

Measures

ğŸŒŸ A pattern is interesting if it is easily understood by humans, valid on new or test data with some degree of certainly, potentially useful, novel, or validates some hypothesis that a user seeks to confirm.

âœï¸ å¦‚æœä¸€ç§æ¨¡å¼â€œå¾ˆå®¹æ˜“è¢«äººç±»ç†è§£â€ï¼Œå¯¹æ–°æ•°æ®æˆ–æµ‹è¯•æ•°æ®â€œæœ‰æ•ˆâ€ï¼Œå¹¶å…·æœ‰æŸç§ç¨‹åº¦çš„â€œè‚¯å®šã€æ½œåœ¨æœ‰ç”¨ã€æ–°é¢–â€æˆ–â€œéªŒè¯ç”¨æˆ·è¯•å›¾ç¡®è®¤çš„æŸäº›å‡è®¾â€ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆè¿™ç§æ¨¡å¼å°±æ˜¯æœ‰è¶£çš„ã€‚

Objective or Subjective

Objective: based on statistics and structures of patterns, e.g., support, confidence, etc.

Subjective: based on userâ€™s belief in the data, e.g., unexpectedness, novelty, actionability, etc.

all or only interesting patterns

All: Completeness

Only: An optimization problemâ€“challenging

  • Can a data mining system find only the interesting patterns
  • approaches
    • First generate all the patterns and then filter out the uninteresting ones.
    • Guide and constrain the discovery process.

7ï¸âƒ£ Research Issues in Data Mining

  • Mining methodology
  • User interaction
  • Applications and social impacts
